awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Resolving Spatial and Temporal Variations in Near Shore Wind Stress via Advances in High Frequency Radar
awd_abstract_narration:
Wind is a critically important driver of ocean waters, so observations of surface winds as they vary in time and location are important to our understanding of ocean circulation. How water moves in the regions near continents can affect the movement of commercial fish stocks, search and rescue efforts, and many other human endeavors in the nearshore region. Yet available buoy or satellite-based wind observations lack the resolution in time and space needed to fully capture the wind as it drives coastal waters.  Today, a distributed network of oceanographic radar systems exists which measure ocean currents remotely from land-based stations.  This project will use these radars to also observe winds remotely over the range and resolution needed to capture the wind's full effects on the coastal ocean.  It will expand on recent efforts to extract the wind's signal from the observations collected by oceanographic radars in Massachusetts, Rhode Island, and California. The team will also deploy wave buoys and autonomous surface vehicles to ground-truth the data collected and refine the models used to translate radar returns into wind speed and direction.  These observations will aid weather forecasts, and improve our understanding of the coastal ocean.


Existing observations of the surface winds from buoys or satellites provide either high temporal coverage or high spatial coverage of the nearshore, but never both. Land-based high frequency (HF) radars have the potential to fill this observational gap. This work will couple recent theoretical results, high quality radar observations, and independent wind and wave observations to further develop HF radar-based wind extraction models.  Using new and existing datasets from both the New England Shelf and Santa Barbara Channel, this effort seeks to improve our understanding of the complex relationship between surface winds and the signals observed by HF radar systems. Validation studies will be carried out in areas observed by multiple types of radar systems and with significant spatial structure in the surface wind field, using both fixed buoy and mobile, Autonomous Surface Vehicle (ASV)-based wind sensors.  These observations will be used to refine our understanding of the relationship between surface wind stress and the signal observed by HF radars, enabling accurate and spatially dense observations of wind forcing throughout the coastal zone.  The proposed effort will advance recently developed wind extraction models and strengthen parameterized links between radar backscattered power and wind speed and direction.  Applying recent developments in direction finding methods and developing improved calibration techniques, the method will be generalized to arbitrary radar systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In Collaborative Research: Resolving Spatial and Temporal Variations in Near Shore Wind Stress via Advances in High Frequency Radar, we worked toward remotely sensing the wind using HF radar. Unlike the previous literature, we aimed to use the backscattered radio wave power from resonant ocean surface waves --- the so-called first order backscatter --- building on the methods of Kirincich (2016a). We collected a dataset spanning several months, of ocean surface winds over a large spatial area using autonomous vehicles within the view of several HF radars, capturing strong gradients in wind speed occurring across the Fall transition. These data have been used to assess previous algorithms which relate wind speed and direction to the power received by HF radars, as well as develop new algorithms. These efforts have produced a deeper knowledge of the relationship between wind and HF radar signals, finding factors affecting the relationship between HF radar power and wind. 

 

In Emery and Kirincich 2021 we reviewed the history of HF radar wind observation, establishing the state of the art and further exploring the use of the first order backscatter. Due to its higher signal-to-noise ratio, the first order signal typically has higher directional accuracy, and is useful over greater distances that second order radar backscatter, which have typically been used for observing wind and waves. This review identified the need to improve the understanding of factors affecting the attenuation of radar waves propagating over the ocean surface.

 

Factors affecting the radar attenuation were investigated in Kirincich and Emery 2023, where we used a long term record of direct measurements of received power to examine the variability of the energy losses along the ocean path over time due to changes in the local environment. Variations were closely related to changes in ocean wave conditions. The predicted effect of the surface gravity waves on path loss was highly dependent on the estimate of the wavefield used, with simpler representations proving to be more accurate. We also found that ocean temperature and corresponding conductivity has negligible effects on radar attenuation. The primary driver of attenuation is the surface roughness, as quantified by the height of ocean waves with lengths near the Bragg resonant frequency (or ocean waves with lengths of about half the radar wavelength). 

 

Our studies also investigated the effect of the scattering patch area on the received HF radar power. Most previous works either assumed simplified scattering patches, or used phased array antennas, for which we have a better understanding of the scattering patch area that results from the use of beam forming. The HF radars used in this analysis use a compact receive antenna, along with algorithm based direction finding, and the corresponding scattering patch area is not as clearly defined. In Emery and Kirincich (in review), we used in situ wave measurements to estimate the area of the scattering patch within a range cell, showing that the patch area can vary by factors of 2-3. Scattering patch area variability thus must be accounted for when attempting to attribute received signal powers to wind speed and direction. 

 

A preliminary effort to investigate HF radar currents and winds resulted in an improved quantification of the observations of submesoscale eddies in a 10 year record of surface current observations. As shown by Payandeh et al. 2023, Submesoscale eddies were found to occur in certain locations over time, forming hotspots of eddy activity, largely in association with topographical features, but in other locations with unobvious topographic or atmospheric forcing. On seasonal scales, eddies were more numerous in the summer and early fall, while at inter-annual scales, eddy counts increased by 40% in association with the 2014--2015 marine heatwave and the 2015--2016 El Nino. A domain-wide diurnal cycle was observed in the formation of eddies, suggesting an important forcing from diurnal winds. The prevalence of hotspots of submesoscale eddies, and the relatively high frequency of occurrence, suggest follow-on efforts with directed in-situ observation, guided by HF radar current measurements, possibly including coincident HF radar based wind observations.
